titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to Jack McCaine NASA papers, 1963-1994, bulk dates 1964-1979 MS 045
titlestmt.author: Sharon Link

publicationstmt.publisher: Woodson Research Center, Rice University, Houston, Texas

note.p: Stored offsite at the Library Service Center and require 24-hour notice for retrieval. Please contact the Woodson Research Center at 713-348-2586 or woodson@rice.edu for more information.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-03-31 09:39:05 -0500.

did.head: Collection Summary

repository.corpname: Woodson Research Center, Rice University, Houston, Texas

did.abstract: Photographs, correspondence, maps, charts, and memorabilia collected by McCaine while employed at Project Manager for the Army Corps of Engineers during the construction of the Manned Space Center (Johnson Space Center), 1962-1964 and while working with NASA, 1964-1979.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Jack McCaine was born in 1923 in Houston. He attended Texas A&M College prior to WWII and graduated in 1950 from the University of Houston with a Bachelor of Science degree in Architecture.

He joined the Spacecraft Center Area Office, U.S. Army Corps of Engineers in 1962. From August 1962 - January 1966, Jack McCaine was employed as project manager for the design and construction of the Mission Control Center, Buildings 30 and 48, and an addition to the Central Heating and Cooling Plant, Building 24 at the Manned Spacecraft Center. This project had an extremely tight schedule, being tied to the space program in progress. This was a first--no one had built a Mission Control Center before. He was project manager for design of Project Engineering Facility, Building 45, which is a seven-story office building. He was also manager for design of Test Operations Support Facility, Building 32A. This was an addition to the large vacuum chamber building.
In addition to the above, he handled specification-writing chores for the Area Office, plus various small projects.
From January 1966 to June 1975, he was an architect, with the Engineering Division, Manned Spacecraft Center, which became the Johnson Space Center in 1973.

Some of the projects that he was responsible for include the design of Engineering Building 17, which is a two-story office building, the design of Systems Integration and Mockup Facility, Building 9a. This is the facility (a large, air conditioned hanger) that contained the full-scale mockup of the Shuttle which visitors were allowed to visit. The West end of the facility contained a large air-bearing floor that was a first-of-its-kind.

Jack McCaine was also Project Manager for various projects such as a proposed addition to Emergency Power Building 48. While in his position, he was responsible for facility preparations for Presidential visits, astronaut returns and other events.
He also handled facility modifications for various exhibits, the museum area of Building 2 and updated and maintained construction guide specifications for JSC.

From June 1975 to December 1979, he served as a General Engineer in the Engineering Division, Nasa, Johnson Space Center. In this capacity, he was Manager of the Construction Services Contract. This contract provided day-to-day, on-site services for modifications to buildings and facilities. This included a work order system handling all types of construction tasks and employing 40 to 60 craftsmen plus superintendents, estimating and accounting support. This effort provided construction services for a wide range of tasks and normally had 200+ tasks in the system at one time.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Jack McCaine Collection consists of approximately 6.75 linear feet of newspapers, books, magazines, brochures, posters, photographs, certificates, charts, memorabilia, awards and recognitions. There is also approximately .25 linear feet in the vault.

Since most of the material covers the decade of the sixties, when the Space Center was called the Manned Spacecraft Center (the name changing to the Johnson Space Center in 1973), the early name will be used throughout the collection.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Stored offsite at the Library Service Center and require 24-hour notice for retrieval. Please contact the Woodson Research Center at 713-348-2586 or woodson@rice.edu for more information.

acqinfo.head: Acqusistion Information
acqinfo.p: The collection was a gift from Jack McCaine to the Woodson Research Center at Rice University on October 15, 1991 with addendums received in 1999, 2000, and 2001.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This material is arranged in the following series:

list.head: Missing Title
list.item: Series I: Publications, 1968-1994; 2.25 cu. ft. Boxes 1 - 4-a
Series II: Public Affairs, 1965-1974; 0.5 cu. ft. Box 5
Series III: General Photographs, 1963-1969; 0.75 cu. ft. Box 6
Series IV: Construction of the Manned Spacecraft Center, 1963-1982; 0.5 cu. ft. Box 7
Series V: Awards and Presentations, 1969-1979; 0 .75 cu. ft. Box 8 and Vault
Series VI: Memorabilia, 1969-1979; 0 .25 cu. ft. Box 9 and Vault
Series VII: Oversize, n. d.; 1.75 cu. ft. Box 10 and Drawer 34

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Jack McCaine NASA papers, 1963-1994, MS 45, Woodson Research Center, Fondren Library, Rice University.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Permission to publish from the Jack McCaine Nasa Papers must be obtained from the Woodson Research Center, Fondren Library.

controlaccess.head: Places
controlaccess.geogname: United States. National Aeronautics and Space Administration

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of newspapers, newsletters, books, and magazines.

The Roundup, later known as the Space News Roundup and the Personnel Newsletter are newspapers; published for the personnel at the Manned Spacecraft Center. Nasa Activities consist of monthly Nasa highlights and is distributed to all Nasa personnel.
The Publications series is organized first according to subject and then chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Both color and black and white photographs can be found in the General Photographs series. Some of the more interesting photographs are ones taken of the exterior and interior, before and after renovation of the Lunar Planetary building, (originally the Jim West mansion,) which is adjacent to the Johnson Spacecraft Center.

Also located in this series is a photograph album containing serial photos taken of the Manned Spacecraft Center during different phases of construction. The photos have been removed from the album and placed in acid free sleeves.

did.unittitle: Autographed Photos of Seven Original Astronauts
Lunar and Planetary Building (Interior, before Renovation)
Lunar and Planetary Building (Interior, after Renovation)
Aerial View of Manned Space Center JSC
Photo Album (transferred to acid free sleeves)

odd.head: General note
odd.p: See Boxes 5 and 10 for Additional Photos

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Public Affairs has an assortment of interesting material used generally for publicity purposes such as the Presentation Packets, and autographed photographs of the Original Seven Astronauts. The Fact Sheets consist of pertinent information on individual Gemini and Apollo flights.

did.unittitle: Publicity Photos, Spacecrafts and Views from Space
Series IV: Construction of Manned Spacecraft Center, 1963-1982

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: An inventory list of the financial costs for construction of various buildings at the manned Spacecraft Center and a list of Corps of Engineer Contracts can be found in this series.

did.unittitle: Manned Spacecraft Center Inventory Detail List
Photograph and Drawing of Mock-up and Integration Laboratory
Basis for Design for Additions to Building No. 48
Assembly and Dismantling Instructions Horn and Shroud Assembly Contract
Architectural Drawing, Temporary Facilities for Mobile Quarantine Facility (MQF) Reception

odd.head: General note
odd.p: See Boxes 6, 6A and Box 10 for Photos of MSC

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Some of the most interesting material in the collection can be found in the Awards and Recognition series. Jack McCaine received many awards and recognitions during his years of working on the constriction of the Manned Spacecraft Center. Among the more interesting ones are the letters received from President Richard Nixon and Frank Borman, thanking him for his contributions to the space program.

A piece of the heat shield from "Auora Seven" (the Mercury flight of Scott Carpenter in May of 1962), along with some interesting medallions and group achievement awards can also be found in this series.

did.unittitle: Correspondence, Certificates, Medallions, Jewelry and Plaque
Jack McCaine from President Nixon, (see Archivist for Original)
Mrs. Jack McCaine from Robert R. Gilruth (with Memento of Lunar Landing)
Group Achievement Award, Lunar Landing Team
Group Achievement Award, Lyndon B. Johnson Space Center
Group Achievement Award, Manned Spacecraft Center
Cuff Links, Tie Tacs and Pins

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Items collected by Jack McCaine during the years of his association with the Manned Spacecraft Center can be found in his series. An assortment of flags representing various countries, along with a collection of patches commemorating different flights, are among the interesting items in this series.

did.unittitle: Dedication of the LBJ Space Center
Pins, White House and Apollo II

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The material in this series is a mixture of various items found in some of the other series, but which will not fit into the standard size boxes.
There is also an interesting assortment of charts, such as an Apollo Earth Orbit charts, and Atlas of Mars and Skylab 4 Mission chart.

Although there is a General Photograph series, photos that were generated for publicity purposes can be found in the Public Affairs series. The Oversize series was formed to hold material that will not fit into standard size archival boxes. Additional photos and memorabilia can be found in the Oversize series.
Some of the oversize items have been placed in Map Case Drawer 34. These items have been listed within the appropriate series.
The collection is divided into seven series, with sub-series as necessary.
